MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Atmospheric Entry lesson! This is an involved lesson, and will be the last one of the basics needed to operate the Command Module.
You are currently in a 300 km x 300 km circular orbit around the Earth.

We will set the ORDEAL to ORB RATE for this mission for simplicity. Once you have learned P52, I would recommend you to try this lesson but using the ORDEAL set to INRTL and then use P52 for a fixed attitude reference instead.
Set the ORDEAL to EARTH.
Then set the ORDEAL FDAI 1 to ORB RATE.
The first thing we will do is the perform the SPS burn in retrograde direction. Please open the MISSION PAD and open the SPS DEORBIT & ENTRY checklist.
We will use P30 to set up the burn and P40 to perform the burn. I advice you to reference to the AGC chapter in the manual, following the steps for P30 and P40 while going through this lesson.
Before we continue, please know this lesson will go through the basic steps needed to land. The process is so involved that I think it's best to learn the major tasks needed first.
Once you know those, you should be able to practice using the checklists and perform the more realistic procedures. But use the checklist as a reference throughout the lesson.
Open the CSM Burn Planner and plan an entry burn with an entry interface angle of about 2 degrees. Set the phase to 260, the dV to 475, the direction to RETROGRADE, and press REQUEST.
When ready, start program 30 using V37E 30E.
P30 should start by displaying V06 N33. The three registers will show the time to ignition in hours, minutes and seconds.
You can change these values but the burn tool should have uplinked the correct values.
Press PRO to continue.
When ready, P30 will display V06N81, the Impulsive Delta V at TIG in Local Vertical Coordinates.
This is used to set the amount of delta V burn in a vector format, allowing the burn to happen in a given direction. We wish to burn in the retrograde direction.
The value is already populated by Mission Control after using the burn tool.
Press PRO to accept the values. The computer will spend a few seconds on calculations before displaying V06N42.
V06N42 shows the Ap and Pe altitude, and the magnitude of the dV burn. Press PRO to continue.
V16N45 is now displayed, and shows the time to ignition in R2.
Press PRO to accept, the AGC will now automatically start P00.
Next we need to orient the spacecraft into the correct burn attitude.

To do this, we will use V49E. This will load R62, the routine used for auto-maneuvering. Complete the routine. As we are in Local Vertical mode, set R3 to +18000 using V23E, and set R1 and R2 to +00000.
When the spacecraft is in the correct attitude, open the Mission Pad and follow the (P40) G&N SPS Thrusting checklist to execute the burn. You can either RUN it or follow it manually.

P40 is now running. This will show V50 N18. Verb 50 Noun 18 means Request Maneuver: Desired FDAI Auto-maneuver Attitude. Please note that when you press PRO, V06 will display as the manuver is executed.
The maneuver is complete when V50 is displayed again. Press PRO again when the maneuver is complete to fine align. V06 should again display.
V50 N18 is flashing again, press ENTER to break the automaneuver routine and continue with the P40 program flow.
V50 N25 if now flashing with R1 set to 00204, meaning Please Perform: Checklist Item: 204.
Complete the gimbal check, P40 will show V06 N40 when it is complete.
V06 N40 now shows the time to ignition, dV to be gained and the accumulated velocity. Continue with the checklist.
When the countdown shows that it's 35 seconds left, the registers will blank for 5 seconds to indicate the burn is close.
When it's 5 seconds left, V99 N40 is displayed. This means that the astronaut approval is needed to execute the burn. Press PRO to accept.
Once PRO is pressed, and the SPS is armed, and the countdown reaches zero, the burn will execute.
V06 N40 will again display, showing the status of the burn.
The engine will automatically stop when the burn is complete, and R2 should show zero, or a fraction below zero.
Complete the checklist.
Next we will prepare for Reentry.

The EMS also needs to be set up. Set the mode to V0 Set, then set V0 to the 25500 line as we are performing an Earth Orbit entry. To do this, press INC on the dV/EMS SET thumb switch a few times so the script line is aligned with the display line.
Set the ENTRY EMS 0.05g switch to UP to ARM the EMS.
Then set the EMS mode to ENTRY and keep it in STBY.
The initial program to prepare for entry is P61, the Entry Preparation program.
On the CMC, run V37E 61E to start the entry preparations.
The first input will be the predicted latitude and longitude of the splashdown location, and the last is if the initial entry will be heads up (+1) or heads down (-1). This controls the lift vector.
The capsule has been designed to have an aerodynamic lift vector, and is opposite of the direction of the heads. So if the heads are pointing down, the vector points up etc.
This vector is used to maneuver the capsule during entry, just like an aeroplane.
Press PRO to accept the default values.
Next, V06N60 shows predictions for entry, like the predicted g-force, velocity at entry interface and flight path angle between the inertial velocity and the local horizontal at the entry interface.
The entry interface is at around 400k of altitude.
Press PRO to accept the values. The next screen shows more predictions like range to go from 0.05g, the predicted velocity at 0.05g and time until 0.05g.
Press PRO to accept. P61 now automatically moves to P62 - the CM/SM Separation and Preentry Maneuver.
P62 first displays V50N25, with 41 in R1. This means Please Perform: Checklist item: 41. This is CM/SM separation.
Check the SPS DEORBIT & ENTRY CHECKLIST, section 30.
The CM RCS system needs to be enabled, as the SM RCS system will be jettisoned soon. Verify that the CM RCS LOGIC is set to ON.
Set the CM RCS Propellant 1 system on MDC-2 to ARM (UP).
Do the same for the CM RCS Propellant 2 system. The CM RCS system will now automatically be ready when the SM is jettisoned.
Then pressurize the CM RCS by setting the CM RCS PRESS switch to up. This requires that the pyros are armed.
Set the SC CONT to SCS.
Then we will need change our power source. So far in this mission, the Fuel Cells has been the primary source of power.
Since these are located in the Service Module, we will loose them when we separate it. The Entry and Post Landing batteries will take over as the primary power source.
These are located inside the Command Module. To tie them to the Main Bus, set the Main Bus Tie A/C switch to UP.
Do the same for the Main Bus Tie B/C switch, set it to UP.
The batteries should now be powering the Command Module.
Next, we will configure the C&WS to not throw master alarms due to warnings from the SM. Switch the C&WS mode from CSM to CM.
We will now perform the SM-separation. To do this, set the CM/SM Sep switch 1 to UP.
Then, set the CM/SM Sep switch 2 to UP.
The SM is now separated and drifting away from the Command Module.
Press PRO on the computer.
This activates the entry DAP and once again displays predicted landing point and gives you an opportunity to select the initial lift vector.
Use the view selector to move the view to the COMMANDERS WINDOW, set the controls to manual and correct the attitude so you are facing head down, and the FDAI is showing the target PGNS attitude.
A the line crossing the entire window at 31.7 degrees indicates the relative angle between the horizon and the X-axis of the spacecraft. The horizon should be within 5 degrees from this line.
Press PRO to accept the data, then set the to SC CONT to CMC and the CMC MODE to AUTO. The CM will now move into the entry attitude, and when within limits, the CMC will automatically proceed to P63.
P63 initially displays V06 N64, showing the current drag acceleration, velocity and range to splash. Key V16E to monitor this.
The program will mainly keep you updated with the drag acceleration, and will automatically move to P64 at 0.05g. The DAP will maintain a stable attitude.
Using orbital view, focus on the CM and use timescale until the CM passes the EI mark. P64 will start once 0.05g is detected.

When you are at the EI mark, press GDC align to align the GDC with the inertial platform. The roll pointer on the EMS will now show you the correct up/down direction, and is used to maneuver through the atmosphere.

Set EMS mode to NORMAL. By the way, I also recommend you to try to set the controls to manual (power the RHC and set CMC to FREE). You will only need to control roll as the other axes are controlled by aerodynamic forces.
P64 will decide the next step based on many factors, such as vertical speed. For Earth Entry, it will move to P67.
When in P67, the roll is used to guide the capsules lift vector and towards the splashdown point. This is when the high G forces take place. The EMS will draw a line showing the G force and velocity.
Set the SC CONT to SCS as soon when the entry guidance is complete (P67 displays V16 N67). Check Landing checklist on the Mission Pad.
Insert the two ELS fuses on the left hand MDC-8 panel (the lowest row of fuses). Close ELS Bat A first.
Then close the ELS BAT B.
Then ARM the ELS LOGIC on MDC-1, it's a protected switch.
The chutes will now deploy, starting with the drogue, then the main and then splashdown. This system is automatic, but can manually be controlled using the push buttons on MDC-1.
Drogue chute is deployed!
Main chute is out!

Good job today, there was a lot in this lesson, but it's a demanding phase. Please know we skipped many important steps and setup. The next lesson will be the exam. It will be similar to this, but you will follow the mission pad checklists.
This concludes the tutorial, feel free to watch it splash down as well. :)

Title: Lesson 9 - Atmospheric Entry
Description: Atmospheric Entry is a demanding phase of the mission. A lot of preparations are needed, and the last part of the spacecraft, the command module capsule, will make the final journey and splash down into the ocean. This lesson will use the SPS to set the trajectory back through the atmosphere, and the computer to guide the capsule through.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Atmospheric Entry is the last phase of any Apollo Mission and must be carefully planned and executed.
It's an involved mission phase and it's important to double check the steps and the values.

In this lesson we will go through the steps needed to perform the entry burn using the SPS, then separate from the Service Module.
Using what's commonly referred to as the 60's, namely Program 61 - 67 on the Command Module computer, we can prepare the computer for entry.

P61 - Entry Preparation
P62 - CM/SM Separation and Preentry Maneuver
P63 - Entry - Initialization
P64 - Entry - post 0.05g
P65 - Entry - Up control
P66 - Entry - Ballistic
P67 - Final Phase

We will start orienting the CSM to retrograde direction, before using P30 and P40 to perform the needed burn.
Then we will follow checklists and set up the computer for entry.

The EMS, Entry Monitoring System, is heavily used during entry and will display the optimal entry path.

After the 60's, the parachute deployment sequence starts, before splashing down into the ocean.


Good luck!
